channel.title: Latest PHMSA Hazardous Materials Incident Reports, for WI

item.title: Report I-2024050075
item.description:
Report I-2024050075

Identified by scraper @ 2024-05-30T18:16:39+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-04-30
  • City: Germantown
  • State: WI
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: N&M TRANSFER
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: According to the information obtained, the following occurred. While at customer location, a leak was discovered coming from nose of trailer. Free product was contained to asphalt surface beneath trailer and trailer floor. Upon inspection, one 55-gallon drum was discovered punctured. Approximately 10 gallons of free product had released from the damaged drum. Customer contracted with a local vendor to perform the cleanup. Absorbent material was utilized on the asphalt and within trailer to absorb product and clean affected areas. Damaged drum was overpacked andno further action was required. There was no impact to soil or threat to enter state waters. There were no injuries or exposures reported.

item.title: Report E-2024050465
item.description:
Report E-2024050465

Identified by scraper @ 2024-05-24T15:13:39+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-05-14
  • City: JANESVILLE
  • State: WI
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R&L CARRIERS SHARED SERVICES, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 5000
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: On May 14, 2024, one (1) 1-gallon bottle of UN3264 was crushed in transit and released approximately one (1) gallon of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from HazChem Environmental (HCE) to remediate the impacted site. The crew utilized neutralizer and granular absorbents to the release and collected them with hand tools. The damaged bottle and all impacted materials were containerized in one (1) 55-gallon drum for disposal.

item.title: Report E-2024050514
item.description:
Report E-2024050514

Identified by scraper @ 2024-05-24T15:13:39+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-05-13
  • City: NEENAH
  • State: WI
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: DAYTON FREIGHT LINES, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: Dayton Freight personnel observed approximately one hundred (100) pounds of material impacting the trailer floor. The released material originated from two (2) 50-pound paper bags that were improperly loaded. Dayton Freight personnel cleaned the impacted area and containerized the damaged bags and the recovered material into one (1) 20-gallon poly drum. The generated waste was staged onsite at the terminal in a secure location. The generated waste will remain onsite for Dayton Freightâ€™s contracted hazardous waste vendor to coordinate disposal.

item.title: Report E-2024050245
item.description:
Report E-2024050245

Identified by scraper @ 2024-05-24T15:13:39+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2024-05-03
  • City: MENOMONEE FALLS
  • State: WI
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: VEOLIA ES TECHNICAL SOLUTIONS, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Total Amount Of Damages: 0
  • Serious Incident Ind: No
  • Description: A Veolia employee was offloading a trailer when they noticed white powder on the floor of the trailer. An investigation revealed a wrapped pallet with bags containing Aluminum Sulfate had a puncture in the bottom of a bag, spilling out the material. Veolia employees donned proper PPE, cleaned up the spill and overpacked all of the bags into appropriate packaging for continued transportation.
